node.doctext:
This is a storage node for CST reviews. Reviews are moved here from our working area in [CST_Chat].

This archive begins on 10/22/2006, When it's full we'll move to [CST_Storage_24].

See also CST Storage collabs [CST_Storage_1|1] - [CST_Storage_22|22].

Batch Processed on: 10/22/2006 Part 2

Writeup Title:[Kobayashi Issa]
Author:[pos]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: Unknown
Original Author's Permission received?: NA
Quoted content less than 33%: NA
Compliance Assessment: Unknown
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2006-08-08@1:39 [Jack] says Got a nuke request from [pos] that I'm not sure how to deal with. She's claiming that five of her writeups aren't compliant and should be deleted, but they (cursorily) look fine to me. [Haibun|1] [Senryu|2] [Haiku|3] [Kobayashi Issa|4] [Matsuo Basho|5].

Hello Jack, On August 8th there were several write ups by [pos] submitted to [Content_Salvage] for copyright evaluation. Unfortunately it looks like all of [pos]’s write ups have been deleted.

Author: [AppleSticker]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: Yes
Original Author's Permission received?: No
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2006.08.14 at 18:35 jessicapierce says The Psychology of Political Violence
Hi there, I've been asked to review this for copyright compliance and I believe it's okay as long as you cite the 1917 edition of Emma Goldman's Anarchism and Other Essays as your source. Once that's done you can add the [CST Approved] tag.
[CST Approved] per Public Domain, based on the 1917 edition of Emma Goldman's Anarchism and Other Essays

Writeup Title:[macaroni and cheese]
Author:[waverider37]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%: Yes.
Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:2006-08-01@4:17 waverider37 says Hello Lometa, I have written another node with copyrighted text and I thought I might let you know that it is about 25% copyrighted. Just thought I'd let you know.
Hi [waverider37], Wow this is a yummy recipe! Would you like a [CST approved] tag? Recipes are evaluated a uniquely because lists, like ingredients, can’t be copyrighted. One suggestion I would like to make is where the source is listed. A better word would be [excerpt|excerpted] from (title of book etc.) That way the readers know that most of the content is your work and only parts or excerpts are taken from the recipe book. I would be happy to do an evaluation if you can tell me which passages of the recipe have been used.
2006-08-09@11:23 [waverider37] says [Macaroni and Cheese] has no blatant copyrighted materials in that case... I put the recipe into my own words.
That’s terrific [waverider37]! If you would like to you can add the [CST approved] tag.:) =================================================

Author: [Marshall Applewhite]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: Yes
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2006-10-17 (8.8 min) The Debutante says Many of this noder's writeups come from this site. There's nothing on the website to suggest that the work is in the Public Domain, and there is nothing on the fled noder's h/n to suggest he has a direct link to the website (although he does quote the site there). I'm happy to go through and weed-out anything, but thought I'd better seek advice first. Thanks :-)
2006-10-19 GrouchyOldMan: Permission to reproduce the published work of the real Marshall Applewhite and Heaven's Gate on E2 was received from Mark King of the Telah Foundation on 19 Oct. 2006.

Writeup Title:[The Adversary]
Author:[piq]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%:90%
Compliance Assessment: No.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2006-11-08@14:03 [jessicapierce] says I've just deleted a Marrianne Moore poem listed in [Easter Egg Poems], which probably has other copyrighted works as well. ..help?
Hello piq, This write up was submitted to [Content_Salvage] for copyright evaluation. Unfortunately because of the [E2 copyright changes] we can no longer keep copyrighted work in the database. Phyllis McGinley published “The Adversary” in “A Certain Age” in 1960. If you would like to update and resubmit this write up, you may want to read through the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] for suggestions and ideas. If you have any questions or need assistance, please feel free to ask:)

Writeup Title: [The Ascending Soul]
Author: [Jaez]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: Yes
Original Author's Permission received?: No
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Ues
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2006.11.14 at 12:28 paraclete says Okay, here's a fun one for you to get stuck into: everything posted by Jaez in the last 24hrs was written by the thirteenth century Persian poet Rami; however, the English translations of these were done by this guy, http://www.rumi.net/rumi.html, so I'm assuming copyright violation. Have messaged the author about this, but I'll leave the rest up to you.
/msg [Jaez] Hi there, I've been asked to review your Jalaluddin Rumi poems for compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy]. I assume the translations are by Shahram Shiva and are thus copyright protected. Is that the case?
2006-11-16 (7.4 hr) [Jaez] says nope. never heard of Shahram Shiva. Don't know who the translator is, it's a very old book I found the poems in, and it was in Pakistan. I'm talking decades old here, and badly printed.
/msg [Jaez] Thanks for the quick response. I've looked for another Rumi translator who published prior to 1923, the public domain cutoff date, and I can't find one. Unless you can cite a public domain source for the translations I have to remove the writeups.
2006.11.16 at 17:05 [Jaez] says you do realize that we're talking about a book that was in a mansion in Lahore and quite possibly from colonial times? The only reason I recognized that it even WAS Rumi was my uncle had heard the poems in urdu and was able to recognize the meaning, although, to be fair his recitation of them was much much better. English tends to leech the flavour from communication, with the exception of rare and excellent poets, or even the great Bard. I would suggest that unless you can find a direct match for the translated phrases on the net, you would be safe enough to unhide them. I did do some checking and it's not Coleman Barks, and he's th e most profilic/popular Rumi translator at the moment. Never came across Shiva, is he any good?
/msg [Jaez] Thanks for your patience, I think I've about got this figured out, and I have a solution that I think will allow the poems to stay on E2. Technically, your wus are in violation of copyright because they appear to be exact copies of more current translations that are under copyright protection (Arberry,Schimmel). I gather you can't cite a specific Public Domain translation from your old book, so you don't have PD compliance either. E2's copyright policy includes a strong reliance on the good faith of its authors however, and in that respect we trust that you are, in fact, citing an ancient uncopyrighted text for all of your translations. On that basis, I propose to approve them under the condition that you append the story of the source and circumstances of your translations to the body of each of the poems. Properly done, that would be a good addition to the writeups, as well as support a credible claim of both [Public Domain] and [Fair Use compliance].
2006.11.19 at 03:02 [Jaez] says thanks for the heads up but paraclete already dealt with this yesterday - I was waiting till after the weekend to start into the fix list. Thank you for coming up with a solution though, it is very kind of you and warmly appreciated. :-)
you said "It was an interesting problem. I look forward to seeing your notes on the poems, it will add an interesting context. I checked with Lord Brawl and, as long as you add the note, you can node as many Rumi poems as you like. Cheers" to [Jaez] (sent to 1 noder)
2006.11.19 at 17:10 [Jaez] says i'm confused. do i listen to you or paraclete?
you said "Paraclete unhid them on my okay and the chief editor has okayed this solution. What's the problem?" to [Jaez] (sent to 1 noder)
2006.11.20 at 00:42 Jaez says clarity. which is crystal now - i take it i follow your solution. thanks for the input.
you said "Once you've added your note to the poems, you can also add the CST Approved tag if you'd like. It'll avoid future Editorial hassles and earn you some upvotes. FWIW, I found Rumi's poetry very beautiful and evocative." to [Jaez] (sent to 1 noder)
/msg [Lord Brawl] Hey boss, I just completed a fiendishly complicated and time consuming Copyright review and I'd like your imprimatur before I proceed with the author. [The ascending Soul] on my scratchpad for details.
2006-11-18 (6.1 min) [Lord Brawl] says re E2 Scratch Pad: A wise and fair solution as always. I approve, support, uphold, and enthusiastically cheer on this resolution.
